Promoting bicycle mobility in cities has several benefits, including individual and public health benefits (Oja et al., 2011; Woodcock et al., 2009). Moreover, a shift of 5% of vehicle kilometers from cars to bicycles would reduce transport-related greenhouse gas emissions by 0.4% (Lindsay et al., 2011). To promote cycling through infrastructure changes, such as new bike lanes or adjusted traffic light phases, detailed information on current bicycle use is needed in an evidence-based, locally and timely targeted manner (Heesch & Langdon, 2016). This is especially important given scarce resources or when assessing accident cycling safety (Strauss et al., 2015).

Machine learning algorithms have created new research opportunities in this context (Klemmer et al., 2018; Rolnick et al., 2023; Xie et al., 2020). Long-term stationary bicycle counters provide data on sub-hourly, hourly, daily, or annual traffic volumes. However, these counters are costly and are only installed in limited numbers across a road network (Romanillos et al., 2016). To understand how counter measurements can be predicted to interpolate traffic volume beyond those with counters, it is essential to analyze the contributing factors behind counter measurements.

Previous studies have focused on detecting unreliable data and interpolating missing entries (Beitel et al., 2018) or identifying the contributing factors behind counter measurements, including weather conditions, time factors, and socioeconomic indicators (Miranda-Moreno & Nosal, 2011; Holmgren et al., 2017; Miah et al., 2022). However, it remains unclear how the various features used for prediction vary in their importance across time and between counters. This knowledge is crucial for traffic planners when predicting traffic volumes under financial constraints (Yi et al., 2021).

To address this gap, we implement and benchmark various machine learning algorithms for predicting hourly counts of stationary counters within a city, using inputs that have been shown to be pertinent in previous studies. We evaluate the models using the root mean squared error (RMSE). We then explore how the feature importance for various inputs varies over time and space. Finally, we evaluate whether bike-sharing data can be used to interpolate the predictions and generate city-wide estimates of cycling volume on the hourly and street level.

We use the city of Berlin as a case study. Bicycle counter data is available for 19 long-term and 12 short-term counter locations at the hourly level. We also use dockless bike-sharing data from Nextbike and Call-a-bike for nine months in 2019 and seven months in 2022. The data contains the departure and arrival points and times of bike trips. We exclude trips shorter than 100m and longer than 50km, as well as trips shorter than 90 seconds and longer than 10 hours. In addition to cycling data, we use weather, vacation, infrastructure, and socioeconomic indicators to predict bicycle traffic volume.
